State Key Laboratory of Petroleum Molecular & Process Engineering, Shanghai Key Laboratory of Green Chemistry and Chemical Processes, ECNU Engineering Center for Sustainable Carbon, School of Chemistry and Molecular Engineering, East China Normal University Shanghai 200062 China 1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol (CHDM), which has similar structural units to PET (polyethylene terephthalate), is a crucial polyester monomer. Therefore, PET can be directly oriented to synthesize CHDM through tandem alcoholysis and selective hydrogenation. However, use of precious metal catalysts such as Pd or Ru catalyst limits the industrial application. Herein, we developed a new process that converts PET into CHDM in mixed solvent of CH3OH-1,4-dioxane via tandem three-step reactions without the involvement of precious metal catalysts or any separation or purification, including the methanolysis of PET to obtain dimethyl terephthalate (DMT) first, then DMT was hydrogenated over a NiLa-40wt% catalyst to form the intermediate dimethyl 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (DMCD), followed by the further hydrogenolysis of DMCD to CHDM over a Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst to yield CHMD with an overall CHDM yield of .90.2 %. Importantly, the final product CHDM could be separated easily just by distillation because there is a significant difference in the boiling point of CHDM with the by-products. Graphical Abstract Keywords Upgrading PET DMT DMCD CHDM Hydrogenation Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction A large amount of waste plastic cannot be quickly degraded in nature, resulting in significant global environmental challenges. Among these plastics, polyethylene terephthalate (PET) is the most widely used polyester plastic [1]. Its resistance to degradation leads to significant accumulation of PET waste. Therefore, recycling or upgrading of PET has become a focal point of attention. Generally, PET recycling methods are categorized into mechanical recycling and chemical recycling. Mechanical recycling involves the separation of PET materials from surface contaminants, followed by melt extrusion and reprocessing into granular plastics [2]. Chemical recycling involves the regeneration of monomers, oligomers, or other chemicals from plastic waste for the reproduction of virgin plastics or other valuable materials [3]. The plastic regenerated by this method inevitably experiences a decline in quality after multiple cycles due to surface contamination, the presence of additives introduced during plastic production, and repeated heating during the recycling process [4]. Moreover, due to the relatively low oil prices, the recycling of petroleum-based plastics is essentially a low-profit industry, thereby constraining its further development. To address this challenge, the concept of plastic upgrading and reengineering has emerged and received increasing attention. The process does not merely use waste plastics to regenerate virgin plastics but generates value-added products instead, converting useless or low-value materials into value-added materials with new functions [5]. With regards to the upgrading of PET, there are several routes via different intermediates such as bis(2-hydroxyethyl) terephthalate (BHET), dimethyl terephthalate (DMT), 1,4-benzenedimethanol (PXG), 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylic acid (CHDA) and dimethyl 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (DMCD) to the value-added 1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol (CHDM) ( Fig. 1). CHDM is an important monomer for the production of high value-added polyesters such as polyethylene terephthalate-1,4-cyclohexanedimethylene terephthalate (PETG), poly(1,4-cyclohexylene dimethylene terephthalate glycol)) (PCTG), and poly1,4-cyclohexylene dimethylene terephthalate (PCT). For instance, in 2015, Zhang et al. developed a process starting from PET glycolysis through PET-BHET-CHDM. The BHET product from PET glycolysis was extracted and then hydrogenated to bis(2-hydroxyethyl) cyclohexane-1,4-dicarboxylate (BHCD) in the presence of 10 % Pd/C catalyst under a solvent-free condition at 155 °C under 7 MPa of hydrogen [6]. Subsequently, BHCD was converted to CHDM with 87 % yield over a Cu-Zn/Al2O3 catalyst. In another case, Cao et al. proposed a relay catalytic strategy for directly converting PET to CHDM via polyethylene 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (PECHD) as an intermediate. Therein, the undegraded PET was first hydrogenated to PECHD on a Pd/r-GO catalyst in 1,4-dioxane at 120 °C under 6 MPa of hydrogen. Then, the ester groups of PECHD were hydrogenated over an og-CuZn catalyst (prepared using the oxalate-gel-coprecipitation method) at 200 °C under 6 MPa of hydrogen, and the overall CHDM yield reached 95 % [7]. Recently, Wang and coworkers utilized a 0.5Pd5Ni/CeO2 catalyst to convert PET to DMCD in a single step at 150 °C under 6 MPa of hydrogen. Subsequently, DMCD was hydrogenated to CHDM using a ternary CuMgAl catalyst, affording the overall CHDM yield of 72 % [8]. In addition, Xie et al. employed the homogeneous [Ru]-1 and tBuOK catalyst to catalyze the hydrogenation of PET to PXG with a yield of 88 %. Then, the benzene ring of PXG was hydrogenated over a Ru/Al2O3 catalyst to obtain CHDM with 57 % yield [9]. Besides, Liu et al. realized the hydrolysis of PET and the subsequent hydrogenation of the hydrolysis product CHDA in an aqueous phase. Specifically, PET was converted over a Pd/C catalyst to CHDA with 100 % conversion and 84.5 % selectivity at 200 °C under 3 MPa of hydrogen. Subsequently, CHDA was hydrogenated to CHDM on a Ru-Sn/C catalyst with 88.9 % yield, and the overall yield of CHDM in the entire process was 80.1 % [10]. Apart from the above-mentioned combinational pathways for converting PET to CHDM, there are also individual studies on one of single steps in the PET→CHDM conversion, such as PET methanolysis, DMT hydrogenation to DMCD, and DMCD hydrogenolysis to CHDM. It was reported that molten PET could be depolymerized with methanol at 210 °C into DMT and EG. Subsequently, the PET methanolysis conditions have been continuously optimized. Different catalysts and various solvents were applied to the PET methanolysis [11–19]. With respect to the hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD, precious metal catalysts such as Pd and Ru are often used [20–24]. However, the high price of noble metal Pd or Ru has limited their industrial application. Correspondingly, base metal catalysts such as Ni-based catalysts were explored [25,26]. Nevertheless, the performance of Ni-based catalysts needs to be further improved because Ni catalysts can also promote deoxygenation of reactants in addition to catalyze the hydrogenation of CC bond [27,28], leading to decreased selectivity in benzene ring hydrogenation. Additionally, acidic supports such as Al2O3 and zeolites can enhance the deoxygenation efficiency by promoting the cleavage of C-O bonds [29–31]. However, introducing lanthanide metals to the catalyst can modify the acid-base properties and the interaction of lanthanide metals with active metals can further enhance the activity and stability [32–35]. Therefore, Ni catalysts supported on lanthanide metal oxides of La, Ce, Pr are anticipated to exhibit excellent performance in the hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD. During the upcycling of PET to CHDM, ester-related groups must also be hydrogenolyzed, a process typically involving Cu-based catalysts. The industrial pathway applies a CuCr catalyst under 30–48 MPa of hydrogen pressure [36]. However, Cr is environmentally toxic and should be replaced by more environmentally benign Cu-based catalysts [37,38]. As well known, the M2+ and M3+ in layered double hydroxides (LDHs) can be uniformly and orderly arranged between layers. After calcination, LDHs undergo decomposition and structural transformation, resulting in mixed metal oxides with large specific surface area, high thermal stability and chemical stability, as well as uniform dispersion of metal components [39]. Accordingly, ternary CuMgAl, CuZnAl and CuMnAl catalysts were prepared and submitted to the hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM [39–41]. These studies have laid a solid foundation for the conversion and upgrading of PET. Based on these findings, ternary Cu-based catalysts with other elements and compositions derived from the LDHs precursors should be further developed for DMCD hydrolysis to CHDM. Moreover, the multi-step process for upgrading PET to CHDM generates numerous intermediate products. Separation and purification of the target product at each step significantly increases costs. Therefore, upgrading of PET to value-added CHDM via tandem processes without separation or purification of intermediate products is an ideal choice. Herein, we developed a route to obtain value-added CHDM from PET over base metal Ni-based catalysts and environmentally benign Cu-based catalysts via tandem three-step processes, including the methanolysis of PET to obtain DMT first, then DMT was hydrogenated over a NiLa-40wt% catalyst to form the intermediate DMCD, followed by the further hydrogenolysis of DMCD to CHDM over a Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst to yield CHDM with 90.2 % overall yield. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (≥98.0 %), Cu(NO3)2·3H2O (≥99.0 %), Fe(NO3)·9H2O (≥98.5 %), Al(NO3)3·9H2O (≥99.0 %), D-(+)-glucose, Na2CO3 (≥99.8 %) and methanol were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. and used as received. Pr(NO3)2·6H2O (99.9 %), Ce(NO3)2·6H2O (≥99.0 %), citric acid (≥99.5 %), DMT (≥ 99 %) and PET were purchased from Aladdin Industrial Corp. 1,4-dioxane were bought from Shanghai RichJoint Chemical Reagents Co., Ltd. 2.2 Preparation of Ni-based catalysts Ni-based catalysts supported on different lanthanide metal oxides (NiLa, NiCe, NiPr) were prepared by a modified sol-gel method [42]. Taking a NiLa-40wt% catalyst as an example, 10.03 g of Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 6.50 g of La(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 20 mL of deionized water, and then citric acid at a molar ratio of 1:1 to metal ions was added. After that, 10.0 g of glucose was added as a porogent. A gel was prepared by stirring the aforementioned mixture at room temperature for 4.5 h, followed by evaporating the excess water in a 98 °C water bath. The obtained gel was thoroughly dried in an oven overnight at 120 °C. Then, NiLa catalyst precursor was calcined in a muffle furnace at 500 °C for 4 h, followed by further calcination at 800 °C for another 3 h. NiPr-40wt% and NiCe-40wt% were prepared in the same way as controls. 2.3 Preparation of Cu-based catalysts The Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst was prepared by a coprecipitation method. Briefly, 4.84 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, 8.03 g of Fe(NO3)3·6H2O and 3.75 g of Al(NO3)3·6H2O were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water and stirred evenly to obtain metal salt solution. NaOH and Na2CO3 were dissolved in 50 mL of deionized water at the ratio of [OH-]= 1.8 ([M3+] + [M2+]), [CO3 2-] = 2[M3+] to obtain lye. Then, the metal salt solution and lye were dropwise added to the flask at 50 °C. After aging for 5 h, the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst precursor was obtained by washing with deionized water and drying in an oven at 80 °C for 12 h. After calcination at 350 °C for 4 h, the catalyst precursor was reduced before use in a quartz tube in a hydrogen flow at 350 °C for 3 h to get Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst. 2.4 Material characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/max-2550VB/PC diffractometer using Cu Kαradiation (λ = 0.15418 nm) with an operating voltage of 35 kV and a current of 25 mA. The scanning range (2θ) was from 5° to 90° with a speed of 20°/min. N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the samples were measured on a Quantachrome Autosorb-3B system at 77 K after the samples were degassed under vacuum at 300 °C for 4 h. The loadings of Ni of catalysts were detected by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) on a Thermo IRIS Intrepid II XSP. Thermo Elemental IRIS Intrepid II XSP emission spectrometer. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) measurements were performed on an FEI Tecnai G2-TF30 microscope. Samples were evenly dispersed in ethanol and placed on copper grids. Temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a Micromeritics AutoChem II chemisorption analyzer. The sample was purged in flowing He (99.999 %, 50 mL/min) at 500 °C for 3 h to remove the impurity. Subsequently, the samples were cooled to room temperature and then exposed to 10 vol% H2-90 vol% Ar (30 mL/min) for 0.5 h at room temperature. Then, the temperature was heated to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min, and the analyzer recorded the H2 consumption of samples during this process. Temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) was performed on the Micromeritics AutoChem II Chemisorption Analyzer as well to characterize the basicity of samples. The sample was reduced in a hydrogen flow at 500 °C for 3 h, cooled to 50 °C, then exposed to 10 % NH3-90 % Ar gas for half an hour. After purging with He to remove the physically adsorbed NH3, the temperature was heated to 800 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C/min, and the desorption of NH3 was recorded during this process. CO pulse titration was also conducted on the Micromeritics AutoChem II Chemisorption Analyzer. Before measurement, samples were hydrogenated in a hydrogen flow at 500 °C for 3 h first, then cooled to 50 °C. After that, the sample was purged by a He flow at 50 °C for 1 h. Then, 10 % CO-He pulses were introduced for CO chemisorption until the CO uptake could no longer be measured. Ni dispersion was calculated from the CO uptake using the following equation: Ni dispersion (%) = (Vuptake × Mw) /m × 100 Where Vuptake is the moles of adsorbed CO per gram of catalyst (molCO/gcat.), Mw is the atomic weight of Ni, m is the loading of Ni in the catalyst (wt%). CO was assumed to linearly adsorb on surface Ni atoms (Ni: CO=1: 1) [43]. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed on a Thermo Fisher Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer with Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV) as the incident beam. Before measurement, the sample was in-situ pretreated in the reactor accessory of the XPS spectrometer under flowing H2 (99.999 %, 50 mL/min) at 500 °C for 3 h. All binding energies (BE) were calibrated with the C1s peak at 284.8 eV as the reference. Spectral fitting and peak integration were conducted using the Avantage software. Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy of pyridine adsorption (Py-DRIFT) was carried out on the Perkin Frontier FT-IR spectrometer to characterize the acid type. The catalyst was reduced in a hydrogen flow (50 mL/min) at 500 °C for 30 min first. Then, the sample was evacuated under vacuum at 200 °C for 30 min and the background was collected at room temperature. After purging with nitrogen at room temperature for 30 min, the spectrum was recorded. After that, the sample was purged with nitrogen flow at 100 °C for another 30 min and the spectrum was collected again. 2.5 Catalytic test In the first step, PET methanolysis was conducted in a 50 mL stainless-steel autoclave. Typically, 0.7 g of PET was methanolyzed in a mixture containing 10 mL of methanol and 2 mL of hexane. After the autoclave was sealed, nitrogen was introduced and pressurized to 2 MPa. The PET methanolysis was then conducted at 250 °C for 2 h [44]. The reaction mixture was quantitatively analyzed by gas chromatography (GC-FID) (DM-WAX, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) (GC-2014, Shimadzu) using dimethyl phthalate (DMP) as an external standard. Since PET was nearly 100% methanolyzed into DMT monomers, a mixed solution containing methanol, 1,4-dioxane, DMT (the theoretical weight of 0.71 g) and ethylene glycol (EG) was obtained. After that, 8 mL of 1,4-dioxane was added to the above mixed solution to dissolve the precipitated DMT. Then, part of the mixed solution (3.5 mL) containing 0.14 g of DMT was submitted to the hydrogenation of benzene ring in an autoclave over a Ni-based catalyst, which was just reduced in a hydrogen flow at 500 °C for 3 h and then mixed with additional 6 mL of 1,4-dioxane. The benzene ring hydrogenation of DMT was conducted at 150 °C under 6 MPa of hydrogen for 5 h. After the reaction was stopped, the mixture was analyzed using GC-FID (DM-WAX, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) (GC-2014, Shimadzu) and the yield of DMCD was calculated according to the following formula. Then, the Ni catalyst in the reaction mixture was replaced by the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst after pretreated in a hydrogen flow for 3 h for the hydrogenolysis of ester group in DMCD. The hydrogenolysis of ester group was performed at 250 °C, 6 MPa of hydrogen for 2 h. After the reaction, the mixture was analyzed using GC-FID (DM-WAX, 30 m × 0.32 mm × 0.25 µm) (GC-2014, Shimadzu) and the yield of CHDM was calculated according to the following formula. (1) Yield of DMT = ( m Actually produced DMT m Theoretically produced DMT ) × 100 % (2) Yield of CHDM = n Produced CHDM n Theoretically produced CHDM × 100 % = n Produced CHDM n PET repeating units × 100 % For the preliminary optimization of reaction parameters for the Ni-based catalysts, pure DMT was also used as reactant. Briefly, the Ni-based catalyst precursor was reduced at 500 °C for 3 h firstly, and then transferred to the autoclave with 10 mL of 1,4-dioxane and mixed with 0.2 g of DMT. After the autoclave was sealed and flushed with hydrogen for several times to replace air, the autoclave was pressurized with hydrogen to the set pressure. The reaction began with stirring at 900 rpm once the temperature reached the set value. The conversion of DMT and the selectivity to DMCD was calculated according to the following formula. (3) Conversion of DMT = ( 1 − n DMT unreacted n initia l DMT ) × 100 % (4) Selectivity of DMCD = ( n produced DMCD n initial DMT − n DMT unreacted ) × 100 % To optimize the reaction parameters for the Cu-based catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of ester group, pure DMCD was also chosen as reactant as follows: 0.1 g of catalyst precursor of Cu1Fe1Al0.5 was reduced in a hydrogen flow at 350 °C for 3 h firstly and transferred to the autoclave with 7 mL of 1,4-dioxane. After that, 0.5 g of DMCD was added to the autoclave and mixed with the Cu-based catalyst. The hydrogenolysis of ester group in DMCD was performed under the set hydrogen pressure at the set temperature. After the reaction, the conversion of DMCD and the selectivity to CHDM was calculated according to the following formula. (5) Conversion of DMCD = ( 1 − n DMCD unreacted n initial DMCD ) × 100 % (6) Selectivity of CHDM = n produced CHDM n initial DMCD − n DMCD unreacted × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Hydrogenation of benzene ring in DMT to DMCD over Ni-based catalysts Due to that the upgrading of PET to CHDM is via the intermediate DMT and DMCD, there are two steps involved in the conversion of DMT to CHDM. One is the hydrogenation of the benzene ring in DMT to DMCD, and the other is the hydrogenation of the ester group in DMCD to CHDM. Thus, the yield of each step would definitely affect the overall CHDM yield. Therefore, the reaction parameters were optimized for the hydrogenation of benzene ring in DMT to DMCD using pure DMT over Ni-based catalysts (Fig. 1). As mentioned above, although Ni-based catalysts have high catalytic hydrogenation activity, the selectivity is poor due to deoxygenation of the carbonyl group in DMT to generate by-products such as methyl 4-methylbenzoate (MMB) and paraxylene (PX). Some people believe that the acidity on the surface of the Ni catalyst will promote the deoxygenation of the reactants [45]. Therefore, the oxides of lanthanide metals La, Ce, and Pr, with alkalinity were selected to load Ni active sites. Under the same reaction conditions, Ni catalyst supported on LaOx showed higher DMT conversion when compared to those loaded on Ce and Pr oxides ( Fig. 2a). Under the same conditions, the conversion of NiLa-40 % reached 94.2 %, while those on NiCe-40wt% and NiPr-40wt% were only 39.4 % and 49.3 %, respectively, indicating that NiLa-40 % was the suitable catalyst for the hydrogenation of benzene ring in DMT. To explore why NiLa-40wt% is more suitable for the DMT hydrogenation reaction, we conducted relevant characterization for the Ni-based catalysts. Three Ni catalysts had comparable Ni loadings in the range of 35.4–36.8 wt%. N2 adsorption-desorption showed that all the three catalysts were uncharacteristic type IV isotherms ( Fig. 3e). The physicochemical parameters are listed in Table 1. It can be seen that the pore volume of the three catalysts is very small (0.009–0.021 cm3/g), indicating that there are few pores on the catalyst surface. Additionally, three Ni catalysts also had similar specific surface area of 1.9–3.4 m2/g. It seems that the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalysts are not the main factors affecting the catalytic performance of the three catalysts. The dispersion of Ni in the Ni-based catalysts was characterized by CO pulse titration. As a result, the Ni dispersion of NiLa-40wt% catalyst is 13.5 %, while that of NiCe and NiPr are 26.1 % and 26.5 %, respectively. However, based on the Scherrer equation, the NiLa-40wt% catalyst had the average Ni particle size of 18.9 nm, while the other two Ni catalysts had the average Ni particle size of 19.2 and 21.9 nm. These contrary results might be interpreted by that Ni particles were partially covered by La2O3 after reduction of perovskite LaNiO3 precursors. Nevertheless, the Ni particles size may not be the decisive factor influencing the performance of the catalysts. To investigate the reduction behavior and the interaction between Ni and different supports, H2-TPR experiments were conducted. As shown in Fig. 3c, NiPr-40wt% and NiCe-40wt% only showed single hydrogen uptake at 424 °C and 413 °C, respectively for the reduction of Ni3+ to Ni0, in contrast, NiLa-40wt% displayed two distinct hydrogen uptake peaks at 405 °C and 536 °C, attributed to the sequential reduction of Ni3+ to Ni2+ and Ni2+ to Ni0 in perovskite LaNiO3. The Ni3d XPS spectra also confirmed that most of Ni species were reduced to Ni0 during the reduction process (Fig. 3d). NH3-TPD profiles showed that the three Ni catalysts had weak NH3 desorption peaks at 168 °C, 164 °C and 154 °C, respectively. In addition, NiLa-40wt% and NiPr-40wt% also showed medium strong acid sites at 284 °C and 263 °C, respectively (Fig. 3f). Moreover, the acid type was also characterized by pyridine-FT-IR spectroscopy in diffuse-reflectance mode due to that the transmittance of samples is nearly zero. The catalysts showed obvious Lewis acid sites and weak Brønsted acid sites (Fig. S2). It was reported that when the Lewis acid sites are insufficient, the electron-deficient metal sites decreased, thereby lowering the activity for the hydrogenation of aromatic compounds [46]. Meanwhile, others claim that the Lewis acid and Brönsted acid work together to catalyze hydrogenolysis and dehydrogenation, and the Lewis acid sites play an important role in catalyzing hydrogenation [47,48]. The quantitative surface acidity of the catalyst is also calculated and listed in Table 1, among which NiLa-40wt% had the highest total acidity including medium-strong acidity of 0.073 mmol/g and weak acidity of 0.011 mmol/g. In contrast, NiCe-40wt% catalyst had the lowest total acidity (only 0.004 mmol/g of weak acidity). Although enhanced acidity on catalyst leads to easier catalytic deoxygenation, benzene ring hydrogenation is similarly affected by acid sites on the catalyst [45,49–52]. According to the literature [46], when the amount of acid on the catalyst surface was decreased, the reaction temperature needed to be increased to improve the conversion of benzene ring hydrogenation. The NiLa-40wt% catalyst had the highest number of acid sites among the three Ni catalysts, so it afforded the highest conversion of benzene hydrogenation. Therefore, NiLa-40wt% was selected as the standard catalyst for the follow-up studies on the DMT hydrogenation to DMCD. Based on the above results, we propose the possible mechanism of DMT hydrogenation on the NiLa-40 % catalyst. Ni0 is the active site for hydrogen adsorption and dissociation as well as for the adsorption and activation of benzene ring, and CO in the ester group of DMT is adsorbed on the basic site of La3+-O2- [42]. The dissociated hydrogen atoms attack the benzene ring of DMT to release DMCD. Subsequently, the reduction temperature for the NiLa-40wt% precursor was optimized (Fig. 2b). When compared the catalytic performance of DMT hydrogenation to DMT over the NiLa-40wt% catalysts after reduced at different temperatures, 500 °C was the optimal reduction temperature for NiLa-40wt% clearly. According to the H2-TPR curve of the as-calcined NiLa-40wt% catalyst precursor (Fig. 3c), when the reduction temperature is below 500 °C, the reduction of Ni2+ was not entire, resulting in a lower catalytic activity. When the reduction temperature further increases, the activity of the NiLa-40wt% catalyst does not increase any more. The hydrogen pressure definitely affects the hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD. As displayed in Fig. 2c, when the hydrogen pressure was lower than 5 MPa, the conversion of DMT decreased significantly, perhaps because of insufficient hydrogen molecules dissolved in the solvent under lower pressure. This indicates that higher hydrogen pressure was beneficial to the hydrogenation of the benzene ring of DMT over NiLa-40wt%. The reaction temperature of the benzene ring hydrogenation of DMT over the NiLa-40wt% catalyst was also optimized (Fig. 2d). The hydrogenation of the benzene ring in the DMT was greatly influenced by temperature, with the highest DMCD yield of 86.0 % at 140 °C. When the reaction temperature was further increased, although the conversion of DMT increased accordingly, the selectivity to the target product DMCD decreased instead with the increase of temperature, resulting in a decrease in the yield of DMCD. Hydrogenation of DMT to DMCD is an exothermic reaction, so that too high temperature may also lead to the occurrence of side reactions [53]. Afterwards, the reaction time impact was also explored. Clearly, when the reaction was stopped after 4 h, the conversion of DMT reached 94.2 % with 91.3 % selectivity of DMCD (Fig. 2e). The by-product MMB increased with the extension of reaction time. In summary, for the hydrogenation of pure DMT in pure 1,4-dioxane catalyzed by the NiLa-40wt% catalyst, the optimal reduction temperature of the catalyst is 500 °C. Under the conditions of 5 MPa of hydrogen and 140 °C for 4 h, 94.2 % conversion of DMT and 91.3 % selectivity to DMCD can be achieved. 3.2 Hydrogenation of ester group in DMCD to CHDM over Cu-based catalysts Subsequently, the reaction parameters for the hydrogenation of DMCD ester group to obtain CHDM were optimized over Cu-based catalysts. Firstly, Cu-based catalysts with different components prepared by coprecipitation method were screened in the hydrogenation of ester group in DMCD to CHDM ( Table 2). Obviously, the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst showed the highest DMCD conversion (98.6 %) and CHDM selectivity (99.2 %). Of particular note, the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst showed slightly higher selectivity to CHDM than that Cu-600 (CuMgAl) catalyst in our previous work, which achieved a CHDM selectivity of 97.3 % [54]. Furthermore, the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst also behaved very well in the one-pot deep hydrogenation of dimethyl succinate to 1,4-butanediol with excellent catalytic performance and long lifetime stability in our previous studies [55]. In our opinion, Cu is the active site of the hydrogenation reaction; Fe regulates the acidity of the catalyst and interacts with Cu to adjust the electronic properties of Cu sites; while Al acts as a dispersant and also modifies the surface acidity of the catalyst. With optimal molar ratio of three elements, the resultant ternary Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst behaved the best in the hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM. According to our previous studies, the high performance of Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst may originate from the high dispersion (8.6 %) of Cu particles and balanced Cu0/(Cu++Cu0) ratio of 0.55, which is beneficial to the hydrogenation of ester groups. At the same time, the acidity amount is 9.80 μmol/g, which can inhibit the removal of hydroxyl groups [55]. Therefore, Cu1Fe1Al0.5 was selected as the standard catalyst for the catalytic hydrogenation of DMCD to yield CHDM. Then, the reaction conditions for the hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM over the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst were optimized ( Fig. 4). Under 5 MPa of hydrogen pressure and at 250 °C for 2 h, the DMCD hydrogenation over the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst can achieve a DMCD conversion of 98.6 % and a CHDM selectivity of 99.2 %. The ratio of cis/trans was 1/2.2. Distinctly, the hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM is favored by higher H2 pressure (Fig. 4a). When the pressure is lower than 5 MPa, the conversion of DMCD is not satisfactory. When it is further increased to 6 MPa, there is no significant change in the conversion or selectivity. According to the product distribution versus time plot (Fig. 4b), one of the two ester groups of DMCD was hydrogenated to form an intermediate product methyl-4-hydroxymethylcyclohexanecarbxylate (MHMCC). Then, the remaining ester group in MHMCC was further hydrogenated to obtain CHDM. The possible side reaction that may occur in this process is the hydrodeoxygenation of the hydroxyl groups in the product CHDM and the intermediate MHMCC, generating 4-methyl-1-cyclohexanemethanol and 4-methyl-1-cyclohexanecarboxylate methyl ester. 3.3 Upgrading of PET to CHDM via tandem three-step processes With these findings at hand, we want to explore the PET upgrading to CHDM via tandem processes. In the first step, PET was methanolyzed in a mixed solvent containing 10 mL of methanol and 2 mL of 1,4-dioxane at 250 °C under 2 MPa of N2 atmosphere. The methanolysis of PET was completed within 2 h with the yield of DMT approaching 100 %. In the second step, the benzene ring of DMT in the PET methanolysis solution was hydrogenated to DMCD over the NiLa-40wt% catalyst. As mentioned above, PET was methanolyzed in a mixed solvent containing 10 mL of methanol and 2 mL of 1,4-dioxane, while pure 1,4-dioxane was adopted as the solvent for the hydrogenation of pure DMT to DMCD over the NiLa-40wt% catalyst. Therefore, the solvent needs to be further optimized prior to the hydrogenation of PET methanolysis solution over the NiLa-40wt% catalyst. As depicted in Figs. 2f, 1,4-dioxane is more suitable than methanol for the hydrogenation of pure DMT to DMCD over NiLa-40wt%. When the volume proportion of methanol increases, both the conversion of DMT and the selectivity to DMCD decline. Therefore, we adopted a mixed solvent containing 8 mL of 1,4-dioxane and 2 mL of methanol for the hydrogenation of DMT in the PET methanolysis solution over the NiLa-40wt% catalyst. Even though the amount of DMT involved in the PET methanolysis solution decreased from 200 mg to approximately 140 mg, the reaction temperature was also raised by 10 °C to 150 °C ( Fig. 5a) and the hydrogen pressure needed to be further increased from 5 MPa to 6 MPa (Fig. 5b) in order to obtain the comparable results. Besides, the reaction time was extended by 1 h (Fig. 5c). This might be because DMT has a higher solubility in 1,4-dioxane than in methanol at the same temperature [56]. Finally, we found 150 °C, 6 MPa of hydrogen pressure, 5 h was the most suitable reaction conditions for the hydrogenation of DMT in the PET methanolysis solution over the NiLa-40wt% catalyst. Under these conditions, DMT in the PET methanolysis solution can be completely converted to DMCD with 90.4 % selectivity. In the third step, the PET methanolysis solution after experienced the first hydrogenation was directly hydrogenated over the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst after filtration of the NiLa-40wt% catalyst. At the same time, the hydrogenation of DMCD over the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst in mixed solvents containing 1,4-dioxane and methanol with different volume ratios was investigated (Fig. 4c). It was found that the hydrogenation of DMCD was also more suitable in 1,4-dioxane. When the methanol ratio in the solvent increased, the conversion of the reaction decreased. In methanol, the conversion reached only 75.8 %. Considering that the previous-step reaction was performed in a mixed solvent containing 1,4-dixoane and methanol, the reaction conditions may need to be further improved to achieve satisfactory result in the hydrogenation of DMCD in tandem reactions. When the Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst was added to the reaction solution obtained from the PET→DMT→DMCD process (containing 90.4 % DMCD and 9.6 % MMB), DMCD in the reaction solution was not completely converted at 250 °C under 5 MPa of hydrogen for 2 h, consistent with the results of pure DMCD hydrogenation in different solvents. Therefore, the hydrogen pressure was increased from 5 MPa to 6 MPa (Fig. 5d). Under 6 MPa of hydrogen pressure, MMB in the reaction solution from the previous step was completely converted to PX and the conversion of DMCD reached 100 % with 99.8 % selectivity to CHDM. Finally, the overall CHDM yield from PET to CHDM via three-step tandem processes reached 90.2 % ( Fig. 6), which is the highest value for the upgrading of PET without any noble metal up to now ( Table 3). Furthermore, we also want to verify the influence of EG on the upgrading of PET to CHDM via the tandem processes without any separation or purification of intermediates or by-products. Because the alcoholysis of PET is essentially an ester exchange reaction, there is a certain amount of EG in the PET methanolysis solution. According to the calculation, the theoretical content of EG was < 0.05 g in the methanolysis reaction solution which was diluted with 1,4-dioxane. To verify the effect of EG on the hydrogenation of DMT, 0.05 g of EG was added. As a result, the influence of such a trace amount of EG on the DMT hydrogenation to DMCD over the NiLa-40 % catalyst is not obvious (Table S3). Similarly, a trace amount of EG does not affect the result of the hydrogenation of DMCD to CHDM (Table S4). Besides, the reusability of the NiLa40-wt% catalyst in the hydrogenation of DMT in the PET methanolysis solution was also investigated. As displayed in Fig. S1(a), the conversion of DMT gradually decreased with the increase of the recycling number, and finally remained at about 70 % with stable selectivity to DMCD. The possible reason for the loss of catalyst activity was attributed to La2O3 phase transformation into La(OH)3 in combination with some relevant characterizations (Fig. S1). Regarding the separation and purification of the final product CHDM, it can be separated easily from the mixture just by distillation because there is significant difference in boiling points: ethanol (78.3 °C), methanol (64.7 °C), 1,4-dioxane (101 °C), PX (138.4 °C), EG (197.3 °C) and CHDM (283 °C). Additionally, EG from the PET methanolysis can be hydrogenolyzed to ethanol or ethane under the hydrogenation conditions [57], which allows the lower temperature for distillation of by-products. 4 Conclusion We developed tandem three-step processes to upgrade PET to value-added CHDM without the use of noble metal catalysts and without additional separation and purification steps. After the first step of complete PET methanolysis to DMT, base metal catalysts NiLa-40wt% and Cu1Fe1Al0.5 were found very effective for the subsequent selective hydrogenation of DMT and DMCD, respectively. As a result, NiLa-40wt% showed excellent conversion (100 %) and 90.4 % selectivity to DMCD in the hydrogenation of DMT in the PET methanolysis solution. The Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst afforded the complete conversion of DMCD even in the PET methanolysis solution in accompany with 99.8 % selectivity to CHDM. Thus, the overall total CHDM yield reached 90.2 %, surpassing other base metal catalyst systems for the conversion of PET to CHDM. This protocol is an important step towards the future exploration of CHDM conversion from the upgrading of PET using base metal catalysts. It lays the foundation for further optimization and upgrading of the process in the future. CRediT authorship contribution statement Gang Chuan: Methodology, Data curation, Conceptualization. coredata.dc:description: 1,4-cyclohexanedimethanol (CHDM), which has similar structural units to PET (polyethylene terephthalate), is a crucial polyester monomer. Therefore, PET can be directly oriented to synthesize CHDM through tandem alcoholysis and selective hydrogenation. However, use of precious metal catalysts such as Pd or Ru catalyst limits the industrial application. Herein, we developed a new process that converts PET into CHDM in mixed solvent of CH3OH-1,4-dioxane via tandem three-step reactions without the involvement of precious metal catalysts or any separation or purification, including the methanolysis of PET to obtain dimethyl terephthalate (DMT) first, then DMT was hydrogenated over a NiLa-40wt% catalyst to form the intermediate dimethyl 1,4-cyclohexanedicarboxylate (DMCD), followed by the further hydrogenolysis of DMCD to CHDM over a Cu1Fe1Al0.5 catalyst to yield CHMD with an overall CHDM yield of .90.2 %. Importantly, the final product CHDM could be separated easily just by distillation because there is a significant difference in the boiling point of CHDM with the by-products.
